dialogs.original: My lord, you told me you would tell the rest,    When weeping made you break the story off,    of our two cousins coming into London.
dialogs.translated: My lord, you told me you would tell the rest of the story of how our two cousins came into London, since crying made you stop.

dialogs.original: Where did I leave?
dialogs.translated: Where was I?

dialogs.original: At that sad stop, my lord,    Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops    Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.
dialogs.translated: At the sad place, my lord, where people threw dust and garbage on King Richards head from the windows.

dialogs.original: Then, as I said, the duke, great Bolingbroke,    Mounted upon a hot and fiery steed    Which his aspiring rider seem'd to know,    With slow but stately pace kept on his course,    Whilst all tongues cried 'God save thee,    Bolingbroke!'    You would have thought the very windows spake,    So many greedy looks of young and old    Through casements darted their desiring eyes    Upon his visage, and that all the walls    With painted imagery had said at once    'Jesu preserve thee! welcome, Bolingbroke!'    Whilst he, from the one side to the other turning,    Bareheaded, lower than his proud steed's neck,    Bespake them thus: 'I thank you, countrymen:'    And thus still doing, thus he pass'd along.
dialogs.translated: Then, as I was saying: the duke rode through the streets on a royal horse while everyone cried God save you, Bolingbroke! You would have thought the windows themselves were speaking, since so many people, young and old, leaned out their windows to get a look at him, and that the walls were crying out Jesus preserve you! Welcome, Bolingbroke! Meanwhile, he turned his head from one to the other, taking his hat off and speaking to them like this: I thank you, countrymen. And doing that, he went on his way.

dialogs.original: Alack, poor Richard! where rode he the whilst?
dialogs.translated: Oh, poor Richard! Where did he ride?

dialogs.original: As in a theatre, the eyes of men,    After a well-graced actor leaves the stage,    Are idly bent on him that enters next,    Thinking his prattle to be tedious;    Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes    Did scowl on gentle Richard;   no man cried 'God save him!'    No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home:    But dust was thrown upon his sacred head:    Which with such gentle sorrow he shook off,    His face still combating with tears and smiles,    The badges of his grief and patience,    That had not God, for some strong purpose, steel'd    The hearts of men, they must perforce have melted    And barbarism itself have pitied him.    But heaven hath a hand in these events,    To whose high will we bound our calm contents.    To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now,    Whose state and honour I for aye allow.
dialogs.translated: Just like the audience at a theater tends not to like an actor that follows the star player, thinking him to be tedious, mens eyes looked at Richard with contempt; no one cried God save him! No one welcomed him back, but they threw dust on his sacred head: which he shook off with such gentle sorrow, smiling and crying at the same time, that had not God (for some purpose) steeled the hearts of men against sympathy, even a barbarian might have pitied him. But heaven has a hand in these things, and we must go along with Gods will. Were all Bolingbrokes subjects now, and Ive sworn to be loyal to him.

dialogs.original: Here comes my son Aumerle.
dialogs.translated: Here comes my son Aumerle.

dialogs.original: Aumerle that was;    But that is lost for being Richard's friend,    And, madam, you must call him Rutland now:    I am in parliament pledge for his truth    And lasting fealty to the new-made king.
dialogs.translated: He was Aumerle; but his earldom is lost for being Richards friend, and madam, you must call him Rutland now. I will vouch for his loyalty in Parliament.

dialogs.original: Welcome, my son: who are the violets nowThat strew the green lap of the new come spring?
dialogs.translated: Welcome, my son; who are the violets now that celebrate the new spring?

dialogs.original: Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not:God knows I had as lief be none as one.
dialogs.translated: Madam, I dont know, and I dont care: I would rather be nothing than one of them.

dialogs.original: Well, bear you well in this new spring of time,    Lest you be cropp'd before you come to prime.    What news from Oxford? hold those justs and triumphs?
dialogs.translated: Well, behave yourself in this new spring, lest you be cropped before your time. Whats the news from Oxford? Did they hold the jousts?

dialogs.original: For aught I know, my lord, they do.
dialogs.translated: For all I know, my lord, they do.

dialogs.original: You will be there, I know.
dialogs.translated: You will be there, I know.

dialogs.original: If God prevent not, I purpose so.
dialogs.translated: If God doesnt prevent me from going, I plan to be there.

dialogs.original: What seal is that, that hangs without thy bosom?Yea, look'st thou pale? let me see the writing.
dialogs.translated: Whats that letter you have? Why do you look so pale? Let me see it.

dialogs.original: My lord, 'tis nothing.
dialogs.translated: My lord, it's nothing.

dialogs.original: No matter, then, who see it;I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.
dialogs.translated: Then it shouldnt matter who sees it; I will be satisfied in this. Let me see the letter.

dialogs.original: I do beseech your grace to pardon me:    It is a matter of small consequence,    Which for some reasons I would not have seen.
dialogs.translated: I ask your grace to forgive me; its a letter of no importance, which for some reasons I don't want you to see.

dialogs.original: Which for some reasons, sir, I mean to see.I fear, I fear,
dialogs.translated: Which for some reasons, sir, I will see. I fear, I fear

dialogs.original: What should you fear?    'Tis nothing but some bond, that he is enter'd into    For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.
dialogs.translated: What should you be afraid? Its nothing but some receipt for his clothes on the tournament day.

dialogs.original: Bound to himself! what doth he with a bond    That he is bound to?   Wife, thou art a fool.    Boy, let me see the writing.
dialogs.translated: Bound to himself? Why would he have a receipt, if he hasn't paid yet? Wife, youre a fool. Boy, let me see the letter.

dialogs.original: I do beseech you, pardon me; I may not show it.
dialogs.translated: I beg you, forgive me; I cant show you.

dialogs.original: I will be satisfied; let me see it, I say.
dialogs.translated: I will be satisfied; let me see it, I order you.

dialogs.original: Treason! foul treason! Villain! traitor! slave!
dialogs.translated: Treason! Foul treason! Villain! Traitor! Slave!

dialogs.original: What is the matter, my lord?
dialogs.translated: What is the matter, my lord?

dialogs.original: Ho! who is within there?
dialogs.translated: Hey! Who's inside?

dialogs.original: Saddle my horse.God for his mercy, what treachery is here!
dialogs.translated: Saddle my horse. God have mercy, what treachery is here!

dialogs.original: Why, what is it, my lord?
dialogs.translated: Why, what is it, my lord?

dialogs.original: Give me my boots, I say; saddle my horse.    Now, by mine honour, by my life, by my troth,    I will appeach the villain.
dialogs.translated: Give me my boots, I tell you; saddle my horse. Now, by my honor, by my life, and by my word, I'll turn in the villain.

dialogs.original: What is the matter?
dialogs.translated: What's the matter?

dialogs.original: Peace, foolish woman.
dialogs.translated: Be quiet, foolish woman.

dialogs.original: I will not peace. What is the matter, Aumerle.
dialogs.translated: I will not be quiet. What is the matter, Aumerle?

dialogs.original: Good mother, be content; it is no moreThan my poor life must answer.
dialogs.translated: Good mother, don't ask any more questions; my life will have to answer for it.

dialogs.original: Thy life answer!
dialogs.translated: Your life answer for it!

dialogs.original: Bring me my boots: I will unto the king.
dialogs.translated: Bring me my boots; I'm going to the king.

dialogs.original: Strike him, Aumerle. Poor boy, thou art amazed.Hence, villain! never more come in my sight.
dialogs.translated: Hit him, Aumerle. Poor boy, youre shocked. Go away, villain! Never come into my sight again.

dialogs.original: Give me my boots, I say.
dialogs.translated: Give me my boots, I tell you.

dialogs.original: Why, York, what wilt thou do?    Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own?    Have we more sons? or are we like to have?    Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?    And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age,    And rob me of a happy mother's name?    Is he not like thee? is he not thine own?
dialogs.translated: Why, York, what will you do? Will you not hide the crime of your own child? Do we have any other sons? Are we likely to have any more? Arent I too old? And will you take my fair son away from me in my old age, robbing me of the name of a happy mother? Isnt he like you? Isnt he your own?

dialogs.original: Thou fond mad woman,    Wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy?    A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament,    And interchangeably set down their hands,    To kill the king at Oxford.
dialogs.translated: You too-fond crazy woman, will you hide this dark plot? A dozen of them have sworn on God to kill the king at Oxford.

dialogs.original: He shall be none;We'll keep him here: then what is that to him?
dialogs.translated: He wont be a part of it; well keep him here. Then what is that to him?

dialogs.original: Away, fond woman! were he twenty times my son,I would appeach him.
dialogs.translated: Get away from me, fond woman! If he were twenty times my son, I would still turn him in.

dialogs.original: Hadst thou groan'd for him    As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful.    But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect    That I have been disloyal to thy bed,    And that he is a bastard, not thy son:    Sweet York, sweet husband, be not of that mind:    He is as like thee as a man may be,    Not like to me, or any of my kin,    And yet I love him.
dialogs.translated: If you had suffered for him in childbirth as I have, you would be more sympathetic. But now I see: you suspect that Ive been disloyal to your bed, and that hes a bastard, not your son. Sweet York, sweet husband, dont think that: he looks as much like you as any man could, not like me or my family, and yet I love him.

dialogs.original: Make way, unruly woman!
dialogs.translated: Get out of my way, unruly woman!

dialogs.original: After, Aumerle! mount thee upon his horse;    Spur post, and get before him to the king,    And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee.    I'll not be long behind; though I be old,    I doubt not but to ride as fast as York:    And never will I rise up from the ground    Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away, be gone!
dialogs.translated: After him, Aumerle! Get on his horse, ride fast, and get to the king before him to beg his pardon before hes accused you. I wont be far behind you: although Im old, I can ride as fast as York: I wont rise from kneeling until Bolingbroke has pardoned you. Go now, be gone!
